title: Will at least 3.5 million people in New Zealand be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 before 30 December 2021?

Still at 100%. Just putting a few notes here:
* 20.9% of the population has become fully vaccinated in October so far.
* 3.6% became fully vaccinated in the past week. This rate is slowing down, as expected.
* 10.0% more of the population needs to become fully vaxxed to reach the forecast target (owid numbers).
* The lag between 1st dose totals and 2nd dose totals is currently 40 days. A month ago, it was 34 days. It's getting longer, but not by much yet.
* 68.8% (forecast target, owid numbers) had received at least 1 dose by Oct 13. Oct 13 + 40d = Nov 22. This is the earliest possible date 3.5M could likely be reached.
* I expect 3.5M to be fully vaccinated sometime between Nov 22 and ~Dec 20.

I've been at 100% for a while, so just some notes here. 
2,771,914 (54.5%) fully vaxxed as of Oct 17, and 3,276,161 2nd doses given or booked.

Only 50 countries have a greater percentage of the population more fully vaccinated than NZ, down from 56 a few days ago. 
They'll probably be at 3M fully vaxxed and 3.5M vaxxed or booked by sometime between a week from now and the end of Oct. Currently a 38-day lag between 1st and 2nd doses.

I've been at 100% for weeks now. My forecast was very low over the first couple months + of this forecast, so my Brier score will be trashed, but oh well.
Just thought I'd write some notes here. 3,512,376 people have received a first dose as of Oct. 14. 
2,601,443 (52% of total population according to NZ, 51.2% according to owid) are fully vaccinated. 
380k people became fully vaccinated in the past 7 days; 295k in the 7 days before that. 7.5% of the population received a 2nd dose in the past 7 days!
3,204,953 are either fully vaccinated or have an appointment for a second dose. Another 295k need to book and receive a 2nd dose to reach 3.5M.
77 days between Oct. 14 and Dec. 30. 
All that matters now is the lag time between 1st dose totals to 2nd dose totals. Here are the approximate recent lag times (in days) between 1st dose totals and 2nd dose totals for NZ:
Sept 9, 32
Sept 16, 34
Sept 23, 34
Sept 30, 37
Oct 7, 39
Oct 14, 39 The lag grows over time. If I fit a line to this data, I project a lag of 56 days on Dec 30. The lag times will likely not form a line on the time scale of this forecast, but I can't picture the lag growing from 39d today to >77d on Dec 30 in New Zealand. To date, nearly all countries that have reached >=72.0% fully vaccinated have taken <77d to go from <=52.0% fully vaccinated to >=72.0% fully vaccinated; it's not an unreasonable idea. Here are the number of days from <=52.0% fully vaccinated to >=72.0% fully vaccinated for the countries that have gotten that far:
UAE, not available
Portugal, approx 32
Malta, 44
Singapore, 22
Qatar, 55
Spain, 48
Iceland, 63
Denmark, 37
Uruguay, 56
China, not available
Chile, 76
Ireland, 58
Belgium, 58
Canada, 80
Cambodia, 41
The number of days from <=52.0% fully vaccinated to ≥72.0% fully vaccinated ranges from 24 to 80 days for these countries. Out of the 13 countries that have reached ≥72.0% fully vaccinated to date and for which data are available, only 1 of these countries (Canada) took longer than 77 days to move from <=52.0% fully vaccinated to ≥72.0% fully vaccinated. But Canada also took 81 days to move from 52% with at least one dose to 72% with at least one dose, while NZ took 38 days. These are but 2 of many time-consuming ways to look at the situation. Maybe I'll do more another day. Many factors favor full vaccination of 3.5M by Dec 30:
* Full vaccination is required for participation in many activities and mandated for many jobs.
* Delta is starting to spread.
* Second appointments are usually booked with first appointments.
* This coming Saturday is a big vaccination push ("Super Saturday"). I'll bet at least 3.5M will have 2nd doses or appointments for 2nd doses by the end of the day.
* The current shapes of NZ's curves for people with at least one dose and fully vaccinated favor success.
* Supply is not an issue.

I'm basing my estimate on countries that have similar curves, and using their data to project NZ's curve. [1] Below is the:
country - current % of population fully vaccinated - days since they have been at 44% (which is NZ's current %) - average %point growth per day Denmark - 75.34% - 82 - 0.38%
Ireland - 74.2% - 82 - 0.37%
Belgium - 72.59% - 85 - 0.34%
Canada - 71.5% - 85 - 0.32%
Italy - 68.53% - 79 - 0.32%
Norway - 67.19% - 48 - 0.48%
France - 66.29% - 75 - 0.3%
UK - 66.05% - 114 - 0.19%
Germany - 64.31% - 83 - 0.24%
Japan - 62.56% - 39 - 0.48%
Australia - 60.26% - 82 - 0.2%
HK - 56.16% - 38 - 0.32%
USA - 55.32% - 109 - 0.1% Average % growth per day = 0.32% For 3.5m of their population to be fully vaccinated, NZ needs more than 82% coverage. This means, In the 85 days left, they need an average % point increase of 0.45%.  This is possible, but unlikely. Especially when you add the fact that these growth %'s were during the rapid growth period of their curves - which NZ is going through right now. All countries have levelled of and slowed down at around 60-65%, so will NZ. Revising my forecast below. I was initially way too pessimistic about the number of people who would get vaccinated at all in the forecast period; it's clear NZ is going to reach 3.5M who have had at least one dose by somewhere between late Sept and mid Oct. The only question is then how many will follow through with a 2nd dose in the forecast period. As vaccination uptake saturates, the lag between 1st and 2nd doses (or more precisely, the time it takes for the number of people who have had at least one dose to match the number of people who are fully vaccinated) tends to increase. In the US, it's about 78 days right now. In NZ, it's about 33 days right now. I don't think the time to a second dose is going to stretch out to 78 days in NZ in the forecast period, given the way vaccine uptake curves look now. There are 76 days between Oct. 15 and Dec. 30. If 3.5M people have received at least one dose by Oct. 15 (and I'm 99% sure they will have), then I think it's extremely likely NZ will make it to 3.5M fully vaccinated by Dec. 30. (And I should have thought about this earlier, lol.)

I think it's clear that NZ will reach 3.5M people with at least one dose in the forecast period, which is extremely impressive. 36.4k people/day have received a first dose in the past week. That is down from a few weeks ago, say, the week ending Aug. 30, when 53.0k people/day were getting a first dose, but it's still more than enough to make 3.5M possible. There's not far to go to get to 3.5M: 3,015,345 have received at least one dose as of Sept. 16; 484,655 to go. At even 30k people/day, New Zealand would get to 3.5M in early October and will hopefully keep going! Then the question is, will 3.5M follow through and get a 2nd dose by the end of the year? The next few weeks will be telling, as 2nd doses should accelerate to match the accelerations in first doses. Right now, there is an approx 33 day lag between 1st doses and fully vaccinated. If that lag doesn't stretch out too much, NZ should make it.

This is turning out to be way more interesting and instructive that I initially gave credit for. So I revised my estimate upwards only slightly (by 5%) and I am quite off from the crowd and even folks like @belikewater who initially were more pessimistic than I was. This requires some introspection and explanation. a) The most important factor in my calculus is that there is a significant difference in single dose and two-dose vaccination rates across all geographies. While efficiency of the Govt. and resources help in reducing this gap, but the difference still persists. Small countries with (semi) authoritarian regimes managed to get to 70% + first (UAE, Singapore etc), but there were some surprises like Portugal & Spain. Canada is still < 70% at the time of this writing and my mental model sort of puts two other commonwealth nations in the same bucket - the Aussies and the Kiwis. b) I will keep a closer eye on the rate, but the most recent period (last 1.5 months) saw 0.75 m (full) vaccinations, which is half a million a month rate. Yes, this rate is creeping up- I expect it to go to 2/3 million a month. But it usually gets harder in the end, so while sustaining 2/3 million per month for 3 months (roughly) will get NZ over the finish-line, the question is whether it is possible to sustain the rate. I think, it's unlikely, but I will be happy to change my mind.

As of 14/9, 3.2m people with first dose or booked, so that's tracking well. For 3.5 m fully vaccinated we need at least 7m does administered - that's sitting at 4.3m today, so at least another 2.7m to go in 107 days. Current rate of needles-in-arms is still high (~60k/day, 7-day average) but dropping slightly after peaking two weeks ago (80k/day). If we kept going at 60k/day then that only takes 45 days, but it will certainly slow later as we get left with the 'hesitant' and 'denial' populations (the latter being basically intransigent).
Reducing age of vaccination to 12 makes it easier, but there are still ~800k people (rough estimate) who are, as of now, not going to be vaccinated. NZ pop'n estimate at 30 June was 5.1m, so we have 4.3m total pool from which to vaccinate our 3.5m, i.e. 81%.
Supply should not now be a constraint with the bonus shipments from Spain and Denmark, and there is no other infrastructure constraint. Overall, I still think this is going to be tight, but recent events make it more likely than when I made my last forecast, so I'm upping it a bit.

4.4M is the potential pool, so they're looking at 80% fully vaccinated. Currently,  "With 80 percent of its people fully inoculated against COVID-19, Singapore is now the world’s most vaccinated country" (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/29/singapore-vaccinates-80-percent-of-population-against-covid-19) That's it. One tiny, disciplined, very wealthy country. New Zealand is awesome but if they can successfully avoid the 60-70% stall every other OECD country is facing I'll be extremely impressed, gladly take the hit to my score, and promptly book a ticket to go visit. "Indeed, if this rate was maintained the entire rollout would be done by Guy Fawkes on November 5. 80 per cent of the 12+ population would have had a first dose by September 21, in just three weeks, and 90 per cent would manage it by September 29. But it's not quite that simple. Every other large-ish country has seen its vaccine rollout plateau at a certain point – usually in the 60s or 70s, as nations run out of the very eager and start trying to reach the hesitant." https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/126252497/covid19-nz-new-zealands-vaccine-rollout-explained-in-11-charts

The current steepness of the curve for first doses is impressive. There are three parts to this question:
1) How many people live in NZ + how many have already been vaccinated. 
2) How much capacity will NZ have to vaccinate its population (doses, medical workers to vaccinate)
3) How much of that capacity will be consumed / will eligible folks not get vaccinated Let's start with population... 
Getting accurate population numbers for NZ was tricky. After some searching I found the NZ Stats agency which seems legit, the equivalent of ACS or something in the US. These numbers were much higher than the census numbers (census from 2018, this is up to date as of last fall). Nonetheless, it seems like the most accurate + up to date for this country with growing population. https://www.stats.govt.nz/information-releases/national-population-estimates-at-30-june-2021 Total population: 5,106,400
The only age breakdown I could find was...
15–39 years	40–64 years	65 years and over
1,745,400	1,589,500	819,100 Or, a total of 4,154,000 15+. Of those, NZ already has 963,219 fully vaccinated and an additional 714,594 already have 1st dose. Together, NZ needs to fully vaccinate 1,822,187 people to hit their goal.  Now, thinking about capacity...
Last week they vaccinated ~300,000 people. Divide by two in terms of new people vaccinated and 150,000 new people were vaccinated last week. At this pace it'll take NZ just over 12 weeks to vaccinate enough people hit this milestone, which brings us to November 12th. Given the new 6 week delay they are doing between doses, that would mean we'd hit the 3.5million on December 24th. That looks good!  And... capacity is ramping up significantly. See the full page: https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-vaccine-data#daily. Vaccinations by day is growing, number of vaccinators is growing, all trends are up and right.  If anything constrains capacity it seems like it'll be NZ's ability to acquire enough doses. They have currently used 99.5% of their stock. But they have purchase agreements for enough to cover population, and starting September 1st will be vaccinating all ages: https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-vaccine-strategy-planning-insights/covid-19-purchasing-vaccines. There is risk with US boosters and fight between other rich nations. This feels like the biggest risk, especially given the relatively tight window.  Vaccine hesitancy...
It's hard to figure out numbers of vaccine hesitant, but NZ seems to have pretty high intention to get vaccinated relative to other countries that have already started. See here: https://theconversation.com/four-in-five-new-zealanders-plan-to-get-vaccinated-but-many-people-want-more-information-about-vaccine-safety-164322. 80% already plan to get vaccinated and the definitely not is just 8% of the population.  Compared to other countries, this feels low. Social trust seems high in NZ, and the recent lockdowns seem likely if anything to make more people want it. Gut-check against other countries...
A number of countries are already at the 70%+ level NZ would need to hit this number (Canada, Portugal, Singapore). While NZ started late they are a rich country, they are vaccinating enough now to hit it (barely) and capacity is ramping. I think this is pretty likely to hit. I'll go with 83% with the downside being around not getting enough doses.

Minus points because it seems the lag between dose 1 and dose 2 has been increased, it seems. This may delay the threshold needed by year's end. https://www.health.govt.nz/news-media/media-releases/time-between-doses-covid-19-vaccine-extended
Minus points because of potential lag between actually giving the 2nd dose and when someone is technically fully vaccinated.

NZ is doing great so far, at 19.4% fully vaccinated. But as of Aug. 17, only 4 countries in the world have fully vaccinated 70% of the population or more: Malta, UAE, Singapore, and Iceland. They are a relatively small, insulated island community and share some relevant features with Malta, the UAE, Singapore and Iceland, but it doesn't seem likely to me that they'll be able to fully vaccinate an additional 50% of the population in 4.5 months. Their vaccine supply schedule is tight, but even if they get that together, which they well may, I think they'll eventually run up against hesitancy, difficulties and lower motivation among the population that will slow down their vaccination drive. I still think the bottleneck will be near the end of the year. Starting today, everyone age 40+ is eligible to be vaccinated. On Aug. 25, everyone age 30+ will be eligible, and everyone age 16+ will be eligible Sept. 1. (I think these schedules have been moved up, but I'm not sure.) People in many countries have been eligible for months without 70% of the population becoming fully vaccinated; only a handful of countries are at 70% even yet. And it's also not clear whether vaccinations will open up to age 12+ in the forecast period, although that will probably happen. So, contrary to the crowd, I'm lowering my forecast. I hope I'm wrong.

New Zealand also seems very compliant with covid protocols and government recommendations, as evidenced with how well they performed with distancing and quarantine so I don't expect them to run into trouble with lack of interest. Also this target requires reaching 85% immunity amongst 12+, and 71% in total. Although they only recently started mass vaccination in comparison to other countries, I don't think it's extremely likely they'll get it done in the next 5.5 months.

As of now, there are 4.1 million people above the age of 12, meaning that New Zealand will need to vaccinate approximate 85% of this population to achieve this goal. Based on their current adherence to their plan, my initial reaction was that the likelihood would be high (>80%), but upon further consideration, I remembered that most countries consider herd immunity to be around 70-85% and that vaccination efforts may slow as the country nears this level. There may be concerns on reaching this level by the given date, as, at their current rate, it'd take them about 300 days to vaccinate 3.5 million people, but as the vaccination is become available to larger groups of people, the rate has been increasing rapidly. Given the country's general compliance during the pandemic, I'd expect that more than 85% of the population will be willing to get the vaccine, making the main concern availability.

There are 4 million people 16+ in New Zealand. From surveys it shows that 3,263,300 people are likely to get vaccinated/willing to get vaccinated, this estimate is also increasing. Only 7% of people said they are unwilling to get the vaccine. In addition, NZ has been surpassing its vaccination plan and its plan shows the entire population vaccinated by November. This vaccination plan also takes into account of supply, so supply is not a bottleneck concern. The reason this percent is not higher is the difficulty in getting the last 10% of vaccinated individuals to be vaccinated. Countries with high vaccination rates like Israel have been facing difficulties getting people age 12-16 to be vaccinated. While NZ seems to be on track to reach 3.5 million people without this group of people, other countries have had a lull of vaccines as the proportion of vaccinated individuals is about 60%, which would only be about 3 million people.  The overall handling of the pandemic in New Zealand was extremely good, which could suggest a high trust in the public health system and the government. This makes it such that countries with a large proportion of the population already vaccinated not a good comparison.  https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines/covid-19-vaccine-strategy-planning-insights/covid-19-vaccine-research-insights

Looking at the total population of New Zealand, it is at 4.9 million, so having 3.5 million people vaccinated is equivalent to a ~71.18% vaccination rate. As of June 29, according to Scott, there were 444,546 vaccinated individuals, but as of July 2, 2021,  there are at least 1,149,608 doses administered, which is around a 250,000 vaccination rate every 4 days. If we linearly extrapolate (probably incorrect, but not too far off considering the limiting factors), it will take about 3.5 months for 3.5 million people to be fully vaccinated. If we consider the limiting factors of getting vaccinated, it is about the number of vaccines available (actual doses, vaccination sites, nurses, distance) and also the willingness to get vaccinated.  Let us compare the vaccination rate with a US state of similar size (Massachusetts). Vaccinations began around 5.5 months ago, and the rate is already at 61% for 2 dose and a 71% at 1 dose (which means it will be 71% full vaxxed very soon). Also, Massachusetts hit the 1.1 million vaccine mark 4 months ago. Considering that Massachusetts is a larger state with more people and MUCH higher population density (884 vs 47 per square mile), it should make sense for Mass to have a slower vaccination rate, meaning New Zealand's should be higher. Another thing we should consider is that since New Zealand's original COVID response who so swift and efficient, we should consider that their vaccine rollout will be smoother (also considering other nations have experience to lend). All measures point to New Zealand having better vaccine response than a similar territory that has already reached the 70% vaccination mark. Given all this, the probability should be very high, which is why I put it at 85%.

As of June 29, 2021, there 444,546 fully vaccinated individuals in New Zealand. That is equivalent to 9% of the population of New Zealand. I think a big part of this question comes down to the overall population of New Zealand. This is essentially asking whether 70% of the population in New Zealand would be fully vaccinated by the end of 2021. I think when you look at it from this perspective it becomes a different question. I think getting this much of the population is a difficult process. In the country, there are going to be lots of people who do not want to take the vaccine (or give the vaccine to their children), people who are too high risk for the vaccine, and people who are too remote to get or need the vaccine. It is important to consider what percent of the population this entails. If this is just under or above 30%, then there is almost no way that there will be 3.5 million people in New Zealand vaccinated by the end of the year. Looking at the United States, four months ago we were at 9% fully vaccinated and now we are at 47.5% vaccinated with rates starting to significantly slow down. While there are still six months left in this year, it makes it hard to believe that New Zealand will end up getting 70% of their population vaccinated by the end of the year. It is definitely possible, but it would require a large continued support from the government and the people which I do not believe will happen that often.

For 3.5 million people in New Zealand to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19, that would imply a full-vaccination rate of 71.2%. Vaccination adoption rates early on are heavily based on vaccine supply channels and once those ramp up, there is not much of an issue surrounding ongoing supply. Most countries now have excess doses and those are likely to start being exported to countries with lower vaccination rates. However, even as things currently stand, we see that in the past month, nearly 4.5% of the population became fully vaccinated. This was up from roughly 1.5% in the prior month. If Switzerland can continue this trend of increasing the rate of new fully vaccinated individuals by 2.5% per month, this would result in hitting this goal by early December, which seems reasonable as most countries experience an exponential increase in vaccination rates as supply ramps up. Further support of this is the large plan the government has for increasing vaccination rates. On the governments website (https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-vaccine-data) they have a model which estimates hitting 7 million vaccinations by October, which has been relatively spot on to date and would imply easily meeting this 3.5 million people vaccination goal. As a result, it seems likely that getting the vaccines will not be a problem for New Zealand. The biggest obstacle I see is actually attaining mass adoption beyond the 70% mark. It is worth noting that a vaccination rate of 71% is higher than any country in the world is currently at, due to most countries experience a sharp reduction in ongoing vaccination adoption. For example, in Israel, we have only seen an increase of ~ 3% in the past 3 months of fully vaccinated individuals from 62% to 65%. Even with massive vaccine availability, state wide incentives to get the vaccine, and private industry incentives, the United States only increased from 50.38% to 54.22% in the past month. This is due to many individuals hesitancy regarding the safety of the vaccine. In New Zealand this rate is estimated at 1/3. As a result, while I do think that it is more likely than not that 3.5 million people in New Zealand are fully vaccinated by the end of the year, the biggest obstacle proves to be whether they can get the last 10 to reach 71.2%

After checking the rate of new vaccinations in new zealand, it seems as though 5% of the population has been vaccinated within the last month (4.2% to 9.0%).   The graph of vaccination rates is very very linear, with almost no upward convexity as of yet.  This suggests that a 5% estimate going forward is reasonable, but it may increase if vaccination availability improves.  However, as more and more people get vaccinated, you start to have selection bias where the only people left are those who are less eager to be vaccinated.  Thus, I will stick with 5% increase in vaccination per month.  New Zealand has 4.917 million people, meaning they need to have about 71% of the population vaccinated to reach 3.5 million.  Given we have just five months before December 2021, it would take a massive increase in new vaccination rates to reach this 71% (with my estimates right now, they will be closer to 35% on december 1st).  If new vaccination rates can somehow increase 2.5x to  12.5% per month, then they would be at 12.5* 5 + 9 = 71.5% vaccination rate, just barely eclipsing the 71% mark.  However, after reviewing the govt.NZ website, there are extensive plans to increase vaccination rates robustly.  Further, their estimates of vaccination rates compared to realize rates has been extremely accurate so far, making me more likely to believe their lofty predictions (https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-vaccine-data).  Finally, their numbers for those currently vaccinated are well above other sources, and the question specifically refers to the data that is put out by the NZ ministry of health website.  Thus, I am actually starting to think that it is more likely than not that New Zealand will reach 3.5 million vaccinations before December 2021.  However, I still am skeptical of the ability to ramp up vaccinations as much as the ministry of health is suggesting.

3.5m fully vaccinated represents about 70% of the population. Currently NZ is at 9.2% [ https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=People+fully+vaccinated&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=true&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~NZL ] About 1/3 of the population is reported to be vaccine hesitant or skeptical [ https://theconversation.com/more-than-1-in-3-new-zealanders-remain-hesitant-or-sceptical-about-covid-19-vaccines-heres-how-to-reach-them-156489 ] though what we have seen elsewhere is skepticism decline as the population is vaccinated; I would have to investigate but I am assuming social trust indicators in NZ are pretty high, which should help. NZ has had one of the best responses to the virus, or at least some of the lowest rates of infection, which may reduce urgency of people to get vaccinated. Presently, no nation has achieved 70% vaccination (Seychelles is the closest, I believe, at 68.4%). A big driver of this is ongoing scarcity, lack of access, and pending approval of vaccinating younger children. My assumption is by EOY, the vaccines will be approved for people of as young as 5 (possibly 2) and a wealthy, small nation like NZ will be able to procure enough doses to vaccinate their population. [ https://www.marketwatch.com/story/four-covid-19-vaccines-are-being-tested-in-children-and-teens-heres-when-to-expect-a-shot-for-different-age-groups-11620406136 ] At the current pace, roughly 35% of the NZ population will be vaccinated by EOY. Will the pace be able to double, and sustain itself, for the next six months? I am doubtful, what we have seen is an initial surge from eager recipients followed by a tapering off. The question is, at what level will this tapering off occurs when parents can have their children vaccinated?  If you look at Israel (a small, wealthy country), they have struggled to cross the 60% threshold, though 28% of their population is 0-14, and under 12s cannot yet be vaccinated, same as in the US. So, 83% of their eligible population is fully vaccinated. NZ has purchased enough to vaccine their full population, and currently expects delivery in 2H 2021 [ https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-newzealand/new-zealand-to-buy-enough-pfizer-covid-19-vaccines-for-entire-population-idUSKBN2B008J ] So to summarize:
1. NZ has vaccinated 9.2% of its population
2. They're expecting to have enough doses for everyone
3. I'm expecting children 5 and above to be eligible by fall
4. NZ has had few COVID outbreaks
5. Vaccine reluctance/hesitancy is about 1/3 of the population but I expect it to decline with a successful rollout.
6. Pace for the rest of the year would have to roughly double compared to the past 6-8 weeks to exceed 70%.
6. Addendum, NZ is among the least dense countries in the world (210 out of 250 countries or territories) though 84% of the population is in an urban area (slightly higher than the US, for comparison). NZ has the necessary ingredients to cross 70% vaccination, the question will be timing.

Some rough stats: Population ~ 5 million,  target of 3.5 million ~ 70%, time left ~ 6 months, start of clock ~ 3 months ago, vaccinated so far ~ 8%. 
Other relevant info: Indigenous population ~ 25% (Maori + Pacific) where the rate of vaccination is about half of the rest of the population. I think, it might be instructive to compare with Singapore, whose population is comparable and the Govt. is arguably as efficient . In Singapore, the clock started about 4 months ago and they have gotten to 35%. In other words, they were about 3 times faster. The reasons for the difference are important to describe the constraints that NZ faces.
- Population Density/Geography are obviously critical and place logistic limits
- Arguably, NZ enjoys more political freedom and hence may find it harder to ensure vaccination compliance, esp within Maori and Pacific groups. Current vaccination rates : Singapore ~ 9% per month, NZ ~ 2.5% per month. In order for NZ to reach 70% in 6 months, it needs to do it faster than what Singapore has managed so far. Conclusion: Unlikely.

That changes things. 
By the end of 2021, the vaccine will very likely be approved for children possibly as young as age 6 months. The vaccine will likely be approved for children age 12 to 15 in the next few days, less than 2 months after its approval in the US. The vaccine will also almost certainly be approved for age 6 to 11 substantially before the end of the year and may well be approved for children aged 6 mo to 5 yrs in time, too (imo).

0.80*5M = 4M likely demand for vaccine
0.80*4.7M = 3.8M likely demand for vaccine among age 6+
While their health system has never attempted the logistics of something on this scale, hopefully, they can achieve it.

As of today, the total is 381,517 = ~0.4M. So, they'd need to add 3.1M to this total before Dec. 30. 256k more people have had a first dose already. Fully vaccinated currently = ~59.8% of the number of people who have had at least one dose. This percentage is slowly increasing. Let's assume a vaccine will be approved for nearly all or all age groups in New Zealand in time for people who want vaccines to get them before Dec. 30, with the possible exception of, say, under age 5. (Vaccinations for age 12+ will likely be approved within a few days.) The population age <5 is ~300k. The population of NZ was 5M in 2020. It's possible that the vaccine could be available to everyone over age 6 months, too. I can't find current numbers about vaccine hesitancy. In late March, the numbers were ~36%. Suppose it has fallen a bit since then to, say, 30%.
0.70*5M = 3.5M
0.70*4.7M = 3.29M So, it depends a lot on the extent of vaccine hesitancy and which age groups vaccination is open to. This could be very close. Also, the vaccine is currently optional for the general public. Will it be required in schools? There's also the matter that only ~0.2M people have been added to this category in the past month. The rollout has been slow. Hopefully, it will speed up. A lot of uncertainty:
* vaccines are optional, but will they be required for schools?
* vaccine hesitancy may be ~30%
* sufficient vaccines could potentially not be available (but likely will be)
* getting vaccines into arms is logistically difficult and may take longer than hoped, especially among economically disadvantaged and disabled populations. (E.g., plenty of vaccines available in the US, and vaccination started 6 months ago, but only 46.2% are fully vaccinated, even with excess vaccination capacity for weeks.) They have 6 months to go.... They're organized and determined, and they have that in their favor.

The NZ website is very interesting laid out.  It shows the modelled delivery plan for vaccines to year end.  I think this graph is about total vaccines delivered, which means this graph has to exceed 7m for the population to have 3.5m people fully vaccinated (as required by this question).  This looks to be modelled for sometime in October.  However they will be constrained by available doses. While so far it looks like they have had plenty, the current situation looks tight which will slow down vaccination rates. In my view NZ will have reasonably high uptake, so don’t really see a problem with getting to 70pc (3.5m out of 5m pop) especially as they are vaccinating under 18s from the start (according to the data). Think there is a high chance to get there by the end of the year, with the caveat that there are enough vaccines that get to NZ.

Just setting an early position before getting deeper into the research. 3.5 m is about 70% of NZ total population; in some countries/regions 70% seems to be a bit of a plateau point, so given the chance of vaccine delivery delays and other setbacks, I think right now this is just under 50/50. Current MoH plan (https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-vaccine-data) has 8 m doses administered by December... so could be as many as 4m people if they can stick to the plan.

https://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/diseases-and-conditions/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-data-and-statistics/covid-19-vaccine-data introduces a projective model for the total number of vaccines that will be distributed by the end of the year. The model is a high level estimate prepared by the Minstry of Health, and it will be revised continuously. The Model takes into account an expected step increase in supply between July and September with an anticipated increase in the delivery of vaccinations related to the eligible population and anticipated stock levels. According to the model there will be around 8 Mil distributed doses by the end of the year, which corresponds to around 4 Mil people being fully vaccinated.  During the past 6 weeks the actual data has been outperforming the model. Currently, only individuals over 16 years are elligible for vaccination, which accounts for ~4 Mil of the population. It is still unclear if the age group < 16 will be elligible for vaccination until 30 dec 2021. The projections form the model, and its underperformence to the actual data give me some confidence that the answer is yes, but since 4 is still pretty close to 3.5 and it might easily not happen or miss by a little. That's why I would give 58% as my prediciton
